text:
Sixth Avenue, north from West 18th Street, showing the shopping center of this date (1900's). At the right is Siegel-Coopers Department Store, occupying the 18th to 19th Streets frontage. This feature is emphasized in the later view. In the block beyond are Alexanders and Cammeyers stores. Note the absence of the "El" in the limited perspective.

No. 1: May 1906
2: 1940

George L. Balgue
George D. Chinn

View #1

View #1

6th Avenue, intersection of 18th Street. (Before Reconstruction).
March 21, 1920.

Sixth Avenue, at the N. W. corner of W. 18th Street, showing details of the "El" stairway leading to the Downtown platform.

1938-9

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

Sixth Avenue, north from and across West 18th Street, showing mainly the west side of this Avenue.  The corner building with the A. Shulte store was formerly part of Altman's Department Store. This bears No. 615-9 Sixth Avenue and is at the N.W. corner of W. 18th Street.  The store covered the entire block front from 18th to 19th Streets.  The New York Times of March 7, 1939 reports the 1st transfer of this holding since 1817 when it was acquired as farmlands by John Tonnele. He left it in trust for John L. Tonnele who died at the age of 86 years and the tract passed in 1918 to the present sellers.
In making the title search, numerous difficulties arouse because of the inaccurate definitions of boundaries when streets were originally put through, encroachments due to faulty surveys, etc. necessitating a large amount of negotiation finally to clear up the fee.
The Astor interests own the balance of the block front and the combined holdings were divided into two units, of which the southerly portion has now been sold.
March 29, 1939
R.L. Speer

Sixth Avenue, east side, north from West 18th Street, showing prominently the former Seigel-Cooper Department Store building. This occupies the entire frontage of the 18th to 19th Streets block. Above same are additional former retail establishments. These were Alexanders and Cammeyers. Beyond is the office building, No. 7. W. 23rd Street that contains the Masonic Temple. The Empire State Building at 34th Street overshadows this structure.
View 2 emphasises the Seigel-Cooper building. This in its
day was one of the outstanding stores of the city.

View 1: October 28, 1939
View 2: May 1940
6h Ave. from roof at n.w. cor. 19th St.
Neg. A-10  July 17, 1941
P. L. Sperr, photographer

Sixth Avenue, south from West 18th Street, showing this newly recovered Manhattan thoroughfare. The old "El" structure that formerly occupied this zone has been demolished and a municipal subway constructed underground. Prior to the first World War (1917-18) this was the shopping center of the City. Extending from 14th to 23rd Street it later removed to 34th Street. The former Macy Department Store building is clearly apparent in the center of View 1. This is the large building at 14th Street that has two water tanks atop its roof.

View 2 is limited to several of the buildings on the left of the preceding photo. They lie between 17th and 18th Streets. No. 600 (old No. 278) now occupied by the Liberty Shoe Company was formerly the McCrorey Building. The Price and Company Building is self-obvious.

May 9, 1940
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

The former Macy Department Store building is clearly apparent in the center of View 1. This is the large building at 14th Street that has two water tanks atop its roof.

View 2 is limited to several of the buildings on the left of the preceding photo. They lie between 17th and 18th Streets. No. 600 (old No. 278) now occupied by the Liberty Shoe Company was formerly the McCrorey Building. The Price and Company Building is self-obvious.
